questions.text: The most common complication of an ovarian tumor is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Torsion is the most common complication of an ovarian tumor, observed in 12% of cases. It is most frequently seen in benign tumors, with the dermoid cyst being the most common tumor to undergo torsion.

  • Complications of Ovarian tumor can be remembered by the mnemonic TRIP:
    • T - Torsion: Most common complication.
    • R - Rupture: Can be traumatic or spontaneous.
    • I - Infection: A rare complication, seen following acute salpingitis or during puerperium as part of an ascending genital tract infection.
    • P - Pseudomyxoma peritonei: The peritoneal cavity is filled with coagulated mucinous material. In ovarian tumors, it is most common in mucinous cystadenoma and mucinous carcinoma. It is also seen in the mucocele of the appendix and carcinoma of the large intestine. Appendix cancer overall is the most common cause of pseudomyxoma peritonei.

Explanation of Other Options:

Hemorrhage (Option B): While hemorrhage can occur, it is not the most common complication of ovarian tumors compared to torsion.

Infection (Option C): Infection is a rare complication of ovarian tumors, typically occurring secondary to other conditions like acute salpingitis.

Hyaline change (Option D): Hyaline change is a degenerative process within tissues, not a common clinical complication of ovarian tumors in the same category as torsion or rupture.

Key Takeaways:

  • Torsion is the most frequent complication of ovarian tumors, especially benign ones like dermoid cysts.
  • Other complications include rupture, infection (rare), and pseudomyxoma peritonei, the latter being notably associated with mucinous tumors and appendix cancer.

questions.text: Attacks of flushing and cyanosis occur in which type of ovarian tumors:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Attacks of flushing and cyanosis are characteristic symptoms caused by the release of 5-HT (serotonin) from carcinoid tumors of the ovary. These tumors are also called Argentaffinoma and can be primary or metastatic, sometimes occurring as a malignant change in a benign dermoid cyst.

  • Carcinoid tumors of the ovary are sometimes primary and sometimes metastatic.
  • They are also called Argentaffinoma.
  • They can occur as a malignant change in a benign dermoid cyst.
  • Histologically, they are characterized by the presence of solid yellow tumors with the property of reducing silver salts, derived from specialized Kulchitsky cells of the intestine.
  • The production of 5-HT is responsible for the systemic symptoms like flushing and cyanosis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Struma ovarii (Option A): Struma ovarii is a specialized teratoma containing thyroid tissue. It can cause symptoms of hyperthyroidism (e.g., weight loss, heat intolerance), but not typically flushing and cyanosis.

Krukenberg's tumor (Option B): Krukenberg tumors are metastatic gastric carcinomas to the ovary. They typically present with abdominal pain, ascites, and bilateral ovarian masses, but not flushing and cyanosis.

Arrhenoblastoma (Option C): Arrhenoblastoma (now called Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor) is a sex cord-stromal tumor that is androgen-producing, leading to virilizing symptoms (e.g., hirsutism, voice deepening), not flushing and cyanosis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Carcinoid tumors of the ovary release serotonin, causing the characteristic symptoms of flushing and cyanosis.
  • Other ovarian tumors like Struma ovarii and Arrhenoblastoma are associated with different hormonal or systemic effects.

questions.text: In a suspected case of ovarian cancer, imaging work up is required for all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Staging of ovarian cancer is primarily based on surgical exploration according to FIGO staging. Therefore, while imaging can provide information about tumor spread, it is not definitively required for the formal surgical staging itself. Imaging plays a crucial role in delineating the site and size of the lesion, characterization of the lesion into benign or malignant, detecting early metastasis, and assessing resectability.

  • The role of imaging in ovarian tumor includes:
    • Delineating the site and size of the lesion.
    • Characterization of the lesion into benign or malignant.
    • Detecting early metastasis.
    • To assess resectability.
    • To exclude extraperitoneal metastasis (like liver parenchyma, enlarged pelvic and paraaortic nodes, hydroureter and hydronephrosis).
  • The imaging modality of choice is USG for delineating the site and size of the lesion, to devise scoring systems for differentiating benign from malignant tumors, and for screening.
  • Other modalities:
    • Direct radiological examination of the abdomen is used for evidence of fetal skeleton, calcification of leiomyoma, or teeth in a dermoid cyst.
    • Color flow imaging is used to increase the specificity of diagnosis of malignant tumors.
    • CT and MRI are used to evaluate the tumor and the extent of spread but are more useful in monitoring the progress of the disease.
  • The Risk of Malignancy Index (RMI) Scoring System is the method of choice for predicting whether or not an ovarian mass is likely to be malignant.
  • RMI score = Ultrasound score × Menopausal score × Ca 125 level in U/mL.
  • There are 2 scoring systems, RMI 1 and RMI 2, each calculating scores using ultrasound features, menopausal status, and pre-operative CA 125 level.
  • Women with an RMI score > 200 have a high risk of ovarian cancer.

Explanation of Other Options:

Detection of adnexal lesion (Option A): Imaging, particularly USG, is essential for detecting and localizing an adnexal lesion.

Characterization of lesion (Option B): Imaging techniques help in characterizing a lesion as potentially benign or malignant, often using specific features and scoring systems like the RMI.

Assess resectability (Option D): Imaging (like CT and MRI) is vital to assess the extent of the tumor spread and determine if it is surgically resectable.

Key Takeaways:

  • Imaging is crucial for detection, characterization, and assessing resectability of ovarian lesions, and for identifying widespread metastases.
  • However, the definitive staging of ovarian cancer is surgical, not purely radiological.
  • The RMI scoring system uses imaging features, menopausal status, and CA 125 to assess malignancy risk.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with new onset right lower quadrant pain, and you palpate enlarged, tender right adnexa. Which of the following sonographic characteristics of the cyst in this patient suggests the need for surgical exploration now instead of observation for one menstrual cycle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of papillary vegetation on ultrasound is a sonographic characteristic strongly suggestive of malignancy in an ovarian cyst and warrants immediate surgical exploration rather than observation. Other features indicating malignancy include hypoechoic solid areas within the mass, thick (more than 3 mm) nodular septations, a mass greater than 7 cm, and central rather than peripheral vascularity.

USG features of malignant ovarian tumor include:

  • Hypoechoic solid area within the mass (highly echogenic solid areas due to fat or calcification are typical of dermoids).
  • Thick (more than 3 mm) nodular septations / papillary vegetations.
  • Size of mass greater than 7 cm, although very large but simple cysts are usually benign cystadenomas.
  • Central rather than peripheral vascularity.
  • Resistive Index (RI) less than 0.6. RI greater than 0.8 is suggestive of benign disease, but there is an indeterminate range of 0.6 - 0.8.

Explanation of Other Options:

Lack of ascites (Option A): The presence of ascites would be a feature suggestive of malignancy. The lack of ascites alone does not necessarily rule out malignancy or preclude observation, especially if other concerning features are absent.

Unilocularity (Option B): Unilocularity (a single chamber) is generally a feature that suggests a benign cyst. Multilocular cysts with thick septations are more concerning for malignancy.

Diameter of 3 cm (Option D): A diameter of 3 cm is typically considered a small cyst and is often observed, especially if unilocular and without other suspicious features. Masses greater than 7 cm are more concerning for malignancy.

Key Takeaways:

  • Sonographic features like papillary vegetations, solid areas, thick septations, large size (>7 cm), and central vascularity are suspicious for ovarian malignancy and necessitate surgical intervention.
  • Small, unilocular cysts without these concerning features can often be observed.

questions.text: A 20-year-old young girl, presents with a history of rapidly developing hirsutism and amenorrhea with change in voice. To establish a diagnosis you would like to proceed with which of the following tests in blood?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A rapidly developing hirsutism, amenorrhea, and change in voice (hoarseness) in a young woman are virilizing signs that strongly suggest a hormone-producing ovarian or adrenal tumor. Serum testosterone levels may be used to exclude these tumors, as testosterone is the primary androgen responsible for virilization.

  • All masculinizing tumors have a similar presentation characterized by defeminization such as breast atrophy and amenorrhea, hirsutism, acne, hoarseness of voice, muscular development, clitoromegaly, and receding hair line.
  • Removal of the tumor usually restores the secondary sexual characteristics, but hoarseness of voice is often permanent.
  • The most common cause of hirsutism in young girls is PCOD (80% cases). However, PCOD is not associated with hoarseness, and hirsutism in PCOD is not rapidly developing.
  • In PCOD, testosterone levels are raised but are less than 200 ng/dl.
  • It is important to measure testosterone levels, not DHEA, because the main source of DHEA is the adrenal gland and not the ovary.

Explanation of Other Options:

17 OH progesterone (Option A): This test is primarily used for the diagnosis of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH), which can cause hirsutism and virilization, but the rapid onset and specific constellation of symptoms also point strongly to an androgen-producing tumor, for which testosterone is a direct marker.

DHEA (Option B): DHEA (Dehydroepiandrosterone) is primarily an adrenal androgen. While an adrenal tumor could cause these symptoms and elevate DHEA, the question asks for the primary test to establish the diagnosis given the overall picture of virilization. Testosterone is the direct effector of androgen, whether from ovarian or adrenal sources, making it the most direct indicator of androgen excess.

LH + FSH estimation (Option D): LH and FSH levels are primarily used to assess gonadal function and diagnose conditions like PCOD or primary ovarian insufficiency. While relevant for menstrual irregularities, they are not the primary test to detect a rapidly virilizing, hormone-producing tumor.

Key Takeaways:

  • Rapidly developing virilizing signs (hirsutism, amenorrhea, voice change) in a young woman necessitate evaluation for an androgen-producing tumor.
  • Serum testosterone measurement is the most crucial initial test to assess significant androgen excess.

questions.text: A lady has ovarian mass, X-ray pelvis shows a radio-opaque shadow. The probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An ovarian mass with a radio-opaque shadow on X-ray strongly points towards a dermoid cyst as the diagnosis. Dermoid cysts (benign cystic teratomas) commonly contain calcified elements such as teeth or bone, which appear radio-opaque on X-ray.

  • Causes of Pelvic Calcification include:
    • Fibroids: often appear as "popcorn type" calcifications.
    • Dermoid cyst: it is the commonest ovarian mass to calcify.
    • Other ovarian masses: cystadenoma/carcinoma, fibromas.
    • Pseudomyxoma peritonei.
    • Fallopian tube calcification (rare): may suggest TB.
    • Uterine i.e., endometrial calcification from chronic endometritis.
  • Note: Alkylating agents, while used for various cancers, are generally more effective against slow-growing cancers and less effective on rapidly growing cells. Examples include chlorambucil, cyclophosphamide, thiotepa, and busulfan.

Explanation of Other Options:

Mucinous cystadenoma (Option A): While a large ovarian tumor, it typically does not contain calcifications that would be visible as a distinct radio-opaque shadow on X-ray.

Serous cystadenoma (Option B): Similar to mucinous cystadenoma, serous cystadenomas are usually cystic and do not commonly present with radio-opaque shadows on X-ray.

Dysgerminoma (Option C): Dysgerminoma is a malignant germ cell tumor. While it can be a solid mass, it is not typically associated with calcifications that would produce a radio-opaque shadow on X-ray as a primary diagnostic feature.

Key Takeaways:

  • The presence of a radio-opaque shadow on an X-ray of the pelvis in a patient with an ovarian mass is highly suggestive of a dermoid cyst due to its common content of calcified structures.

choices.text: Clinical exam and serial follow up of CA 125

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with a history of treated ovarian carcinoma presents for routine follow-up. Her serum CA-125 level is found to be rising over consecutive visits. She is currently asymptomatic, and no findings are noted on pelvic examination. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In a patient with treated ovarian cancer who is in follow-up and presents with a raised CA 125 level, the next best step is a PET scan. While clinical examination and serial CA 125 are part of routine follow-up, an elevated CA 125 strongly indicates relapse. A PET scan is superior to CT or MRI in this scenario because it can exactly demonstrate whether it is a relapsed tumor or fibrosis (which is common after chemotherapy or radiotherapy and can present as a mass, making differentiation essential).

  • Tumor marker CA 125 is a reliable indicator of disease response or progression in treated ovarian cancer.
    • If CA 125 levels decrease after treatment, it indicates response to treatment.
    • If CA 125 levels increase after treatment, it indicates relapse after treatment.
  • An elevated Ca 125 level predicts persistent disease at second look surgery in 97% of the cases, though CA 125 is not sensitive enough to exclude subclinical disease in many patients.
  • Follow-up in ovarian cancer patients is typically done by physical and pelvic examination along with estimation of CA 125 levels. Patients are advised to visit every 3-4 months for the first 2 years and then 6 monthly for 5 years.
  • Clinical examination and CA 125 together can detect 90% of recurrences. Radiological procedures are not required in all cases.

Explanation of Other Options:

CT (Option A): While CT is used for evaluating tumor extent, it cannot distinguish between a relapsed tumor and fibrosis, making it less definitive than PET in a follow-up setting with rising CA 125.

MRI (Option C): Similar to CT, MRI is good for anatomical detail but may also struggle to differentiate between post-treatment fibrosis and recurrent tumor as effectively as a PET scan, especially in the context of rising tumor markers.

Clinical exam and serial follow up of CA 125 (Option D): While these are standard components of routine follow-up, a raised CA 125 level in a follow-up setting indicates a likely recurrence, warranting further definitive imaging like PET to confirm and localize the disease, rather than just continuing observation.

Key Takeaways:

  • A rising CA 125 level in a patient with treated ovarian cancer strongly suggests recurrence.
  • PET scan is the most appropriate next step to confirm recurrence and differentiate it from post-treatment fibrosis, guiding further management.
  • Routine follow-up includes clinical exam and serial CA 125.

questions.text: Surgical staging of ovarian Ca all done except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

During surgical staging for ovarian cancer, an infracolic omentectomy is performed, meaning the entire infracolic omentum is removed, rather than just an omental biopsy. Surgical staging is performed in all cases of ovarian cancer to accurately determine the extent of the disease.

  • The operation begins by aspirating free ascitic fluid or collecting peritoneal washing.
  • This is followed by visualization and palpation of all peritoneal surfaces and viscera, proceeding in a clockwise manner from the cecum.
  • Next, an extrafascial (simple) hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (BSO) are performed.
  • An infracolic omentectomy is done, which means the entire infracolic portion of the omentum is removed, not just an omental biopsy.
  • In the absence of gross extraovarian disease, peritoneal biopsies are obtained, along with a biopsy or scraping of the right diaphragm.
  • Finally, a pelvic and infrarenal para-aortic lymphadenectomy is completed.

Explanation of Other Options:

Peritoneal washing (Option A): Peritoneal washing is a standard part of surgical staging, performed at the beginning of the operation to collect fluid for cytological examination.

Peritoneal biopsy (Option B): Peritoneal biopsies are obtained in the absence of gross extraovarian disease to check for microscopic spread.

Palpation of organs (Option D): Visualization and palpation of all peritoneal surfaces and viscera are crucial steps in surgical staging to identify any visible or palpable disease.

Key Takeaways:

  • Surgical staging for ovarian cancer involves a comprehensive procedure including peritoneal washings, visualization/palpation of organs, removal of the uterus and ovaries, peritoneal biopsies, lymphadenectomy, and importantly, an infracolic omentectomy, not just an omental biopsy.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female patient has carcinoma ovary with bilateral involvement with ascitic fluid in the abdomen. The stage is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bilateral involvement and malignant ascites are features seen in Stage IC of ovarian cancer. According to the new classification, this would specifically fall under Stage IC3.

  • Superficial liver metastasis is included in Stage III.
  • Metastasis to liver parenchyma is included in Stage IV.

Explanation of Other

II (Option A): Stage II typically involves tumor growth to one or both ovaries with pelvic extension (e.g., uterus, fallopian tubes, or other pelvic tissues), but does not typically include malignant ascites as a defining factor for this stage.

III (Option B): Stage III involves tumor affecting one or both ovaries with peritoneal implants outside the pelvis and/or regional lymph node metastases. While ascites can be present, bilateral involvement with ascites alone would initially classify as IC, and Stage III would require spread beyond the pelvis to peritoneum or lymph nodes.

IV (Option C): Stage IV involves distant metastatic disease, such as metastasis to the liver parenchyma (inside the liver) or distant organs, or malignant pleural effusion. Bilateral involvement with ascites in the abdomen does not directly indicate distant metastasis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Bilateral ovarian involvement coupled with malignant ascites is a defining characteristic for Stage IC ovarian carcinoma.
  • Understanding the specific criteria for each FIGO stage is crucial for accurate diagnosis and treatment planning.

questions.text: Which ovarian cyst does not undergo malignancy:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

None of the listed ovarian cysts are entirely free from the risk of malignant transformation. Each type, including mucinous, papillary (referring to features often seen in serous or other cysts), and dermoid cysts, has a documented rate of malignancy, though these rates vary.

  • The rate of malignant transformation for different tumors is:
    • Serous cystadenoma: 25%-40%.
    • Granulosa cell tumor: 50%.
    • Mucinous cystadenoma: 5%-10%.
    • Dermoid cyst: 1.7%-2%.
  • Among ovarian cysts, the risk of malignancy is maximum with serous cystadenoma and least with dermoid cyst.
  • The most common malignancy seen with a dermoid cyst is squamous carcinoma.

Explanation of Other Options:

Mucinous (Option A): Mucinous cystadenomas have a 5%-10% rate of malignant transformation, indicating they can undergo malignancy.

Papillary (Option B): "Papillary" refers to a growth pattern often seen in serous cystadenomas or carcinomas. Serous cystadenomas have a 25%-40% rate of malignant transformation, making them one of the highest risk types.

Dermoid (Option C): Dermoid cysts have a 1.7%-2% rate of malignant transformation, meaning they can, albeit rarely, become malignant. The most common malignancy associated with them is squamous carcinoma.

Key Takeaways:

  • All types of ovarian cysts, including mucinous, serous (often presenting with papillary features), and dermoid cysts, have some potential for malignant transformation.
  • The risk of malignancy varies among different types of ovarian cysts, with serous cystadenomas having the highest risk and dermoid cysts having the lowest.

questions.text: All are true about serous cystadenoma of the ovary except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The description of multiloculated, sticky, gelatinous fluid is characteristic of a mucinous cystadenoma, not a serous cystadenoma. Serous cystadenomas typically contain a thin, serous, straw-colored fluid and are generally unilocular.

  • Serous cystadenoma:
    • Most common of cystic neoplasms.
    • Accounts for 50% of all ovarian tumors, with 60% being benign, 15% borderline, and 25% malignant.
    • Occur in the 3rd, 4th, and 5th decades of life.
    • Half of the cases are bilateral.
    • It is a unilocular cyst.
    • Delicate papillary excrescences may be seen on the surface and within the loculi of a benign cyst.
    • Histologically, the benign variety shows cystic spaces, and the lining of the tumor consists of tall columnar ciliated epithelium resembling the endosalpinx.
    • The loculi contain a thin serous straw-colored fluid, which may be blood-stained when malignant transformation occurs.
    • The rate of malignant transformation is 40%.
  • Mucinous cystadenoma has a glistening surface and a cut surface that shows loculi filled with mucinous material. The content is thick, viscid, and mucin. The cyst is frequently multiloculated.

Explanation of Other Options:

Bilateral (Option A): Half of serous cystadenoma cases are bilateral, so this statement is true.

Unilateral (Option B): Serous cystadenomas can be unilateral or bilateral, so this statement is also true in some cases.

Concentric calcification (Option C): While not universally present, psammoma bodies (concentric calcifications) can be seen in serous tumors.

Key Takeaways:

  • Serous cystadenomas are typically unilocular cysts containing thin, serous fluid, and about half of them are bilateral. They have a significant potential for malignancy.
  • Mucinous cystadenomas are characterized by multiloculated cysts with thick, gelatinous fluid.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient on USG shows a 3×4 cm clear ovarian cyst on the right side. Next line of management is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

For a premenopausal patient with a small (3x4 cm), clear (simple) ovarian cyst, the most appropriate initial management is wait and watch (conservative management with follow-up).

This typically involves repeating the USG after 1-2 menstrual cycles to assess for resolution or changes.

Explanation of Other Options:

Laparoscopy (Option A): Laparoscopy is an invasive surgical procedure and is not indicated as the initial step for a small, clear, likely physiological or benign cyst in a 25-year-old. It would be considered if the cyst persists, grows, becomes symptomatic, or develops suspicious features.

OC pills (Option B): An existing small, clear cyst, observation is key to see if it resolves spontaneously, making OC pills not the primary "next step" for managing the existing cyst itself.

Ca-125 estimation (Option D): CA-125 estimation is a tumor marker primarily used in the workup of suspicious ovarian masses, particularly in postmenopausal women, or for monitoring known ovarian cancer. For a small, clear cyst in a 25-year-old, the risk of malignancy is very low, and CA-125 is generally not indicated as the initial test.

Key Takeaways:

  • Small, clear (simple) ovarian cysts in premenopausal women are usually functional or benign and often resolve spontaneously.
  • The initial management is typically conservative ("wait and watch") with a follow-up ultrasound to confirm resolution.
  • Invasive procedures or extensive tumor marker testing are not warranted for such benign-appearing cysts unless suspicious features develop or the cyst persists.

questions.text: Krutikaben, 58 years old, complained of pain in abdomen, with USG showing 4 cm bilateral ovarian mass with increased vascularity. Next line of managements:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

For a 58-year-old postmenopausal woman presenting with abdominal pain, bilateral ovarian masses, and increased vascularity on USG, surgery is the next line of management. Any ovarian mass with signs of malignancy (bilateral involvement, increased vascularity) requires surgery irrespective of the size.

Explanation of Other Options:

USG guided ovarian tapping (Option A): This is generally not recommended for suspected malignant ovarian masses due to the risk of spreading malignant cells and often providing insufficient diagnostic material.

Wait and watch (Option B): Wait and watch is not appropriate for a postmenopausal patient with bilateral ovarian masses and increased vascularity, as these are strong indicators of malignancy. Such findings warrant immediate further investigation and definitive management.

OC pills × three cycles (Option D): Oral contraceptive pills are not a treatment for ovarian masses in postmenopausal women and would be inappropriate, especially given the suspicious sonographic findings. Their primary use related to ovarian cysts is sometimes in premenopausal women to suppress functional cysts, but not for suspicious masses.

Key Takeaways:

  • Bilateral ovarian masses with increased vascularity in a postmenopausal women are highly suspicious for malignancy and necessitate surgical exploration.
  • The decision for definitive surgical management should be based on intraoperative findings and pathological assessment.

choices.text: Only follow up without surgical intervention
Cesarean delivery and ovariotomy at term

questions.text: A 15 cm × 15 cm ovarian cyst has been diagnosed in an 8 weeks pregnant lady. Further Management includes:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A 15 cm x 15 cm ovarian cyst diagnosed at 8 weeks of pregnancy is considered a large cyst and poses risks such as torsion, rupture, or potential malignancy. Therefore, surgical intervention is indicated, and the ideal time for such surgery during pregnancy is the second trimester (14-16 weeks). This timing minimizes the risk of miscarriage associated with first-trimester surgery and avoids the increased difficulty and uterine irritability of third-trimester surgery.

  • Dysgerminomas are the most common malignant tumor diagnosed during pregnancy, but overall the most common ovarian cyst diagnosed in pregnancy is a dermoid cyst.
  • The most common ovarian tumor to undergo torsion in pregnancy is a dermoid cyst.
  • The most common time for an ovarian cyst to undergo torsion in pregnancy is the end of the first trimester and/or puerperium.

Explanation of Other Options:

Only follow up without surgical intervention (Option A): A 15 cm cyst is too large to be safely managed with only follow-up, as it carries a significant risk of complications (torsion, rupture) and potential malignancy.

Cesarean delivery and ovariotomy at term (Option C): Waiting until term for a Cesarean delivery and ovariotomy is not ideal for such a large cyst. The risks of complications (torsion, rupture) increase as the pregnancy progresses, and managing a large cyst during delivery can complicate the Cesarean section itself.

Surgery after delivery (Option D): Similar to waiting until term, delaying surgery until after delivery exposes the patient to the risks of complications throughout the remainder of the pregnancy and puerperium. Early intervention in the second trimester is preferred for symptomatic or large cysts.

Key Takeaways:

  • Large ovarian cysts (e.g., >10 cm) discovered in early pregnancy generally require surgical management.
  • The second trimester (14-16 weeks) is the optimal window for ovarian surgery during pregnancy to balance the risks to the pregnancy and the need for timely intervention for the cyst.
  • Dermoid cysts are the most common ovarian cysts in pregnancy and are prone to torsion, especially around the end of the first trimester.

questions.text: Following are a few steps involved in management of stage III ovarian cancer except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Abdominal pelvic radiotherapy has very little scope in the management of advanced stage (Stage III and IV) ovarian cancer, primarily due to the advent and effectiveness of chemotherapy. The primary management strategies for Stage III ovarian cancer include cytoreductive surgery (debulking) and chemotherapy.

  • Management of Advanced stage disease (stages III and IV) in ovarian cancer:
    • Exploratory Laparotomy leads to Cytoreductive or debulking surgery. This includes: Total abdominal hysterectomy bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, complete omentectomy, retroperitoneal lymph node sampling, and resection of any metastatic tumor. (Option A ruled out)
    • Optimum cytoreductive surgery aims to reduce the residual tumor load to less than 1-2 cm in diameter. Lesser the residual tumor volume (less than 1 cm), better is the survival. (Option B ruled out)
    • Chemotherapy: Chemotherapy is used widely following surgery to improve the result in terms of survival. Drugs are given for five or six cycles at 3-4 weekly intervals. (Option D ruled out)
    • Combination chemotherapy: Paclitaxel (175 mg/m2) and carboplatin (400 mg/m2) are commonly used.
    • Neoadjuvant chemotherapy and interval cytoreductive surgery: Few cycles of chemotherapy followed by interval primary cytoreductive surgery may be done. Indications are:
      • Advanced epithelial ovarian cancer.
      • High risk for surgery.
      • Associated comorbid conditions (pleural effusion).
      • Predicted to be suboptimally resected. The patient should have a histological diagnosis of the tumor (biopsy).
    • Benefits of neoadjuvant chemotherapy are:
      • Rapid clinical improvement.
      • Subsequent surgery is easier and morbidity is reduced.
      • Optimum cytoreduction with minimal residual disease may be possible.

Key Takeaways:

  • The cornerstone of Stage III ovarian cancer management involves surgical cytoreduction/debulking followed by chemotherapy.
  • Radiotherapy has limited utility in this setting compared to chemotherapy.

questions.text: Lutein cysts are associated with all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lutein cysts are typically formed due to excessive stimulation by gonadotropins. They are associated with high levels of chorionic gonadotropin (as seen in gestational trophoblastic tumors) or exogenous gonadotropin administration (like during ovulation induction with clomiphene). They are also usually bilateral. Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs), however, generally suppress gonadotropin secretion and therefore prevent, rather than cause, lutein cyst formation.

  • Lutein cysts are usually bilateral.
  • They are caused by excessive chorionic gonadotropin secreted in cases of gestational trophoblastic tumors.
  • These may also be formed with administration of gonadotropins or even clomiphene to induce ovulation.
  • These cysts are usually lined either by theca lutein cells (called theca lutein cyst) or by granulosa lutein cells (called granulosa lutein cyst).
  • Spontaneous regression is expected within a few weeks following effective therapy of the tumors, with the gonadotropin level returning back to normal.

Explanation of Other Options:

Gestational trophoblastic tumours (Option A): These tumors produce high levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which overstimulates the ovaries and leads to the formation of lutein cysts.

Clomiphene administration (Option B): Clomiphene is an ovulation-inducing drug that can lead to increased gonadotropin release and ovarian hyperstimulation, potentially resulting in lutein cysts.

Bilaterality (Option C): Lutein cysts are characteristically bilateral due to the systemic nature of the gonadotropin stimulation.

Key Takeaways:

  • Lutein cysts are associated with high gonadotropin levels, whether from pathological conditions (like gestational trophoblastic tumors) or medical interventions (like clomiphene/gonadotropin administration).
  • They are typically bilateral and regress spontaneously once the underlying cause of gonadotropin excess is resolved.
  • OCPs prevent ovarian activity and gonadotropin surge, thus not associated with the formation of lutein cysts.

choices.text: Stromal invasion is commonly present in ovarian tumours of borderline malignancy
Lymphocytic infiltration is characteristic to dysgerminoma
Presence of ascites and pleural effusion in Brenner tumour indicates poor prognosis

questions.text: True regarding neoplasms of the ovary are:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Both lymphocytic infiltration is characteristic to dysgerminoma and presence of ascites and pleural effusion in Brenner tumor indicates poor prognosis are true statements regarding ovarian neoplasms.

  • Stromal invasion is absent in ovarian tumors of borderline malignancy. The epithelium shows multilayering, cellular atypia, pleomorphism, and mitotic activity, but without invasion into the underlying stroma. (Option A ruled out)
  • Lymphocytic infiltration is characteristic of dysgerminoma. Dysgerminomas are known for their prominent lymphocytic infiltrate within the tumor stroma.
  • Brenner tumor may present with the features of ascites and pleural effusion would indeed indicate a poor prognosis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Dysgerminomas are characterized by lymphocytic infiltration.
  • The presence of ascites and pleural effusion in Brenner tumors imply poor prognosis
  • A key feature distinguishing borderline ovarian tumors from invasive carcinomas is the absence of stromal invasion.
